meanings.definition: The quality of being equal in measure or length.
meanings.sent1: The isometry of the two sides of the rectangle ensured they were of the same length.
meanings.sent2: In geometry, an isometry is when two shapes have the same size and shape.
meanings.sent3: The isometry of the twins' heights made it hard for people to tell them apart.
meanings.sent4: The isometry of the two buildings made them look like mirror images of each other.
meanings.sent5: The isometry of the puzzle pieces made it easy to fit them together perfectly.

meanings.definition: A transformation that preserves distances between points in a geometric figure.
meanings.sent1: The isometry of the translation kept the points in the same relative positions.
meanings.sent2: Using an isometry, the shape was moved without changing the distances between its points.
meanings.sent3: The isometry of the map made it look like the city was closer than it actually was.
meanings.sent4: The isometry of the dance routine made it seem like the dancers were moving in sync effortlessly.
meanings.sent5: The isometry of the reflection in the mirror made it hard to distinguish the original from the image.

meanings.definition: A one-to-one correspondence between the points of one geometric figure and the points of another figure, preserving distances.
meanings.sent1: The isometry between the two shapes allowed for a perfect match of their points.
meanings.sent2: An isometry ensures that each point in one figure corresponds to exactly one point in another figure.
meanings.sent3: The isometry between the two jigsaw puzzles made it challenging to figure out which piece belonged where.
meanings.sent4: The isometry between the two stories was evident in how every detail matched perfectly.
meanings.sent5: The isometry between the two paintings created a seamless transition from one artwork to the other.
